name: IntersectionHrexCoverageAndHRexCoverage
title: Intersection of HRex Coverage Profile And HRex Coverage Profile

element.short: Insurance or medical plan or a payment agreement
element.definition: left: Financial instrument which may be used to reimburse or pay for health care products and services. Includes both insurance and self-payment.; right: This is the Coverage profile which is used to provide insurance information for scheduling an appointment and/or registering a patient.
element.comment: The Coverage resource contains the insurance card level information, which is customary to provide on claims and other communications between providers and insurers.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources

extension.valueString: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions].

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: left: Business Identifier for the coverage; right: Also known as Member identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this coverage.
element.comment: left: The main (and possibly only) identifier for the coverage - often referred to as a Member Id, Certificate number, Personal Health Number or Case ID. May be constructed as the concatenation of the Coverage.SubscriberID and the Coverage.dependant.; right: This must be filled in when known
element.requirements: Allows coverages to be distinguished and referenced.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of the resource instance.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the coverage as not currently valid.
element.requirements: Need to track the status of the resource as 'draft' resources may undergo further edits while 'active' resources are immutable and may only have their status changed to 'cancelled'.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A code specifying the state of the resource instance.

element.short: Coverage category such as medical or accident
element.definition: The type of coverage: social program, medical plan, accident coverage (workers compensation, auto), group health or payment by an individual or organization.
element.requirements: The order of application of coverages is dependent on the types of coverage.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The party who 'owns' the insurance policy.
element.comment: For example: may be an individual, corporation or the subscriber's employer.
element.requirements: This provides employer information in the case of Worker's Compensation and other policies.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: IN1-16, 18,  19-name of insured, address, date of birth

element.definition: The party who has signed-up for or 'owns' the contractual relationship to the policy or to whom the benefit of the policy for services rendered to them or their family is due.
element.comment: May be self or a parent in the case of dependants.
element.requirements: This is the party who is entitled to the benfits under the policy.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: IN1-16, 18,  19-name of insured, address, date of birth

element.short: left: ID assigned to the subscriber; right: Subscriber ID
element.definition: The insurer assigned ID for the Subscriber.
element.requirements: left: The insurer requires this identifier on correspondance and claims (digital and otherwise).; right: The subscriber Id is a number that is needed by the payer to associate the attestation with the member in their system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: IN1-16, 18,  19-name of insured, address, date of birth

element.definition: The party who benefits from the insurance coverage; the patient when products and/or services are provided.
element.requirements: left: This is the party who receives treatment for which the costs are reimbursed under the coverage.; right: This would usually be the US Core Patient Resource for which the service was performed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: IN1-16, 18,  19-name of insured, address, date of birth

element.definition: A unique identifier for a dependent under the coverage.
element.comment: Periodically the member number is constructed from the subscriberId and the dependant number.
element.requirements: For some coverages a single identifier is issued to the Subscriber and then a unique dependent number is issued to each beneficiary.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: - No exact HL7 v2 equivalent concept seems to exist;

element.definition: The relationship of beneficiary (patient) to the subscriber.
element.comment: Typically, an individual uses policies which are theirs (relationship='self') before policies owned by others.
element.requirements: To determine relationship between the patient and the subscriber to determine coordination of benefits.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The relationship between the Subscriber and the Beneficiary (insured/covered party/patient).

element.definition: Time period during which the coverage is in force. A missing start date indicates the start date isn't known, a missing end date means the coverage is continuing to be in force.
element.requirements: Some insurers require the submission of the coverage term.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The program or plan underwriter or payor including both insurance and non-insurance agreements, such as patient-pay agreements.
element.comment:
left: May provide multiple identifiers such as insurance company identifier or business identifier (BIN number).
For selfpay it may provide multiple paying persons and/or organizations.; right: May provide multiple identifiers such as insurance company identifier or business identifier (BIN number).
For selfpay it may provide multiple paying persons and/or organizations.
 When sending payer, it may either be a reference to a record stored on a mutually accessible registry, or the Reference.display and Reference.identifier elements can be used to convey the payer's name and identifer.
element.requirements: Need to identify the issuer to target for claim processing and for coordination of benefit processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A suite of underwriter specific classifiers.
element.comment: For example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group, Policy, Plan.
element.requirements: The codes provided on the health card which identify or confirm the specific policy for the insurer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Type of class such as 'group' or 'plan'
element.definition: The type of classification for which an insurer-specific class label or number and optional name is provided, for example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group, Policy, Plan.
element.requirements: The insurer issued label for a specific health card value.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The policy classifications, eg. Group, Plan, Class, etc.

element.definition: The alphanumeric string value associated with the insurer issued label.
element.comment: For example, the Group or Plan number.
element.requirements: The insurer issued label and value are necessary to identify the specific policy.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Human readable description of the type and value
element.definition: A short description for the class.
element.requirements: Used to provide a meaningful description in correspondence to the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The order of applicability of this coverage relative to other coverages which are currently in force. Note, there may be gaps in the numbering and this does not imply primary, secondary etc. as the specific positioning of coverages depends upon the episode of care.
element.requirements: Used in managing the coordination of benefits.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: - No exact HL7 v2 equivalent concept seems to exist;

element.definition: The insurer-specific identifier for the insurer-defined network of providers to which the beneficiary may seek treatment which will be covered at the 'in-network' rate, otherwise 'out of network' terms and conditions apply.
element.requirements: Used in referral for treatment and in claims processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A suite of codes indicating the cost category and associated amount which have been detailed in the policy and may have been  included on the health card.
element.comment: For example by knowing the patient visit co-pay, the provider can collect the amount prior to undertaking treatment.
element.requirements: Required by providers to manage financial transaction with the patient.

element.definition: The category of patient centric costs associated with treatment.
element.comment: For example visit, specialist visits, emergency, inpatient care, etc.
element.requirements: Needed to identify the category associated with the amount for the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The types of services to which patient copayments are specified.

element.short: The amount or percentage due from the beneficiary
element.definition: The amount due from the patient for the cost category.
element.comment: Amount may be expressed as a percentage of the service/product cost or a fixed amount of currency.
element.requirements: Needed to identify the amount for the patient associated with the category.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A suite of codes indicating exceptions or reductions to patient costs and their effective periods.
element.requirements: Required by providers to manage financial transaction with the patient.

element.definition: The code for the specific exception.
element.requirements: Needed to identify the exception associated with the amount for the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The types of exceptions from the part or full value of financial obligations such as copays.

element.short: The effective period of the exception
element.definition: The timeframe during when the exception is in force.
element.requirements: Needed to identify the applicable timeframe for the exception for the correct calculation of patient costs.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: When 'subrogation=true' this insurance instance has been included not for adjudication but to provide insurers with the details to recover costs.
element.comment: Typically, automotive and worker's compensation policies would be flagged with 'subrogation=true' to enable healthcare payors to collect against accident claims.
element.requirements: See definition for when to be used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The policy(s) which constitute this insurance coverage.
element.requirements: To reference the legally binding contract between the policy holder and the insurer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
